<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(const char *Str, size_t DataLen)
{
    ssize_t WriteLen;

    while (DataLen > 0)
    {
        /* writes the raw data directly to STDOUT_FILENO (unbuffered) */
        WriteLen = write(STDOUT_FILENO, Str, DataLen);
        if (WriteLen <= 0)
        {
            /* no recourse if this fails, just stop. */
            break;
        }
        Str += WriteLen;
        DataLen -= WriteLen;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No controlling expression in the provided function is invariant. The only loop is: while (DataLen > 0) — its controlling expression depends on the parameter DataLen, which is modified inside the loop (DataLen -= WriteLen), so the condition is variant and must be evaluated each iteration. There are no do-while or for loops with constant/compile-time conditions, nor any infinite-loop constructs that would fall under the allowed exceptions. Therefore there are no code fragments that require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 in this function.
